results.title: Clover Lawns Are Blooming in Front Yards, and on TikTok
results.abstract: Amid droughts and extreme heat, people are welcoming clover into their lawns, an alternative to the purely grass lawn, helping them save water and money.

media.caption: For homeowners trying to maintain pleasant lawns, clover can be a less expensive and more resilient alternative to grass.
media.copyright: Amanda Mary for The New York Times

results.byline: By Jason DeParle and Maddie McGarvey
results.title: Expanded Safety Net Drives Sharp Drop in Child Poverty
results.abstract: With little public notice and accelerating speed, child poverty fell by 59 percent from 1993 to 2019, according to a comprehensive new analysis that shows the critical role of increased government aid.

media.caption: When Stacy Tallman’s family in Marlinton, W.Va., had a financial crisis, the government safety net allowed her to weather it without her children falling into poverty.

results.title: When You Can’t Stand the Sound of Chewing (or Crunching, or Sniffling)
results.abstract: Misophonia, a little-known syndrome, is characterized by strong negative emotional reactions to certain sounds or visual cues.

results.title: James Stewart Polshek, Quiet Giant of Modern Architecture, Dies at 92
results.abstract: He took a sensitive, socially conscious approach to projects including the Clinton library and the renovated entrance to the Brooklyn Museum.

media.caption: The architect James Stewart Polshek at his office in Manhattan in 1985. “The true importance of architecture,” he once said, “lies in its ability to solve human problems, not stylistic ones.”

results.abstract: His forthcoming book, “The Song of the Cell,” part of what he says will be a quartet, is “fundamentally about understanding the units that organize our life.”

results.title: As Harvard Makes Amends for Its Ties to Slavery, Descendants Ask, What Is Owed?
